Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Education: Building a Skilled Software Verification and Validation Community

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration: Software quality is a crucial issue due to industry's general lack of knowledge of Verification and Validation (V&V) benefits and the shortage of V&V practitioners. This project improves software education at the undergraduate level and enhances on-the-job professional training, thereby increasing the pool of professionals with V&V knowledge and skills. The project team consists of an academia-industry collaboration involving seven academic programs and four industry partners, and possesses experience in software development, course development, and project management. The project team is critically examining the existing V&V course at Robert Morris University, enhancing and modularizing selected topics, and improving delivery strategies by incorporating academic research findings and industry best practices. The cogent modules and strategies developed are being assessed, evaluated, and shared among project participants and disseminated to other institutions through an NSF supported centralized repository (NSDL), conferences, publications, professional societies, and websites. Students and practitioners are being equipped with fundamental theoretical knowledge and invaluable hands-on experiences that are measurably increasing their ability to contribute to the industry.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project Outcome Report


Software quality remains a crucial issue due to industry’s general lack of knowledge of Verification and Validation (V&V) benefits and the shortage of V&V practitioners. Through this project we have made a significant impact in software quality. We have improved software education at the undergraduate level and enhanced on-the-job professional training, thereby increasing the pool of professionals with V&V knowledge and skills. Newly developed active learning tools consisting of case studies, class exercises, and case study videos have been instrumental in achieving project outcomes. This project has: 

 

i. Developed V&V community spanning industry and academia

Timely and active participation and contribution by academic and industry partners enabled a group of like-minded individuals to develop friendship and trust and contribute to the successful execution of this project. Though seven (7) academic and four (4) industry partners were proposed to commit to using the materials developed through this project, thirty-one (31) academic and five (5) industry partners have already become beneficiaries. Academic instructors and industry partners are forging new avenues of cooperation by identifying internships and job opportunities as well as research collaborations. They are also discussing future projects. One academic partner has been awarded a fellowship based on the outcomes of this project and is developing active learning tools for their software gaming program. Most academic and industry partners understand that work on improving the courseware will continue and are eager to communicate and share best practices beyond the project period itself.

The active learning tools are available through two courseware repositories: project website www.rmu.edu/nsfvv and ENSEMBLE http://www.computingportal.org/EnsembleCollections?q=sdd. Assessment reports are available in conference proceedings, and journal papers. The four case study videos are also available in YouTube and in average have received 130 views.


ii. Improved V&V teaching and learning opportunities

This project has developed 44 delivery contact hours of cogent course modules in the area of Software Verification and Validation in the form of case studies, class exercises, and case study videos. Thirty-one (31) academic partners have received course modules or have been directed to the course material repositories. Many of these partners have incorporated one or more of the active learning tools in their existing courses or have developed entire new course for their CS, IS, or SE curriculum. Some of the institutions have shared their student surveys after delivery of course modules. Course delivery strategy using the flipped classroom model, has minimized traditional lectures and maximized hands-on experiences. A delivery plan, in the form of mini learning workshops focused on communication skills, applied knowledge of methods and tools, and application of research has been developed. Industry partners have asked their subordinates to refer to case study videos to get further understanding on V&V concepts. 

Academic and industry partners were polled regularly throughout the project period to understand the use of the active learning tools.

 

iii. Improved knowledge and skills pertaining to V&V.

The project has responded to the National Research Council’s (NRC) challenge “to deliver effective undergraduate education in STEM disciplines,” namely the challenge of providing engaging laboratory, classroom, and field experiences through improved communication skills, applied knowledge of methods and tools, and research exposure. An academia-industry partnership has critically evaluated Robert Morris University’s V&V course contents, performed gap analyses vis-à-vis academic research and industry best practices, and used the ADDIE model to develop a compelling sequence of course modules that focuses on four aspects of V&V: requirements engineering, reviews, configuration management, and testing. The development and review were driven by an academia-industry partnership and by academic research and industry best practices. The beneficiaries of these robust partnerships, the students and practitioners, are now equipped with not only fundamental theoretical knowledge, but also with invaluable hands-on-experience that has measurably increased their ability to contribute to the industry. A number of students at the PI’s institute have obtained internships and full time employment. Also 7 students have successfully completed an Associate CMMI certification (administered by Capability Maturity Module Integration – CMMI Institute).


The tangible results of the new V&V course material has improved teaching resources for use in both university level curriculum and industry on-the-job training programs. During the project duration 6 journal papers 8 conference papers have been published and 3 poster presentations have been made. An academic partner was able to get a fellowship and was promoted to full professor.
